leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 19] s 19 Commencing and carrying on proceedings (cf Act No 9 1973, sections 53 and 56; Act No 11 1970, section 22)

leg:heading.title: Commencing and carrying on proceedings (cf Act No 9 1973, sections 53 and 56; Act No 11 1970, section 22)

p.text: Subject to this Act, proceedings are to be commenced and carried on in the manner prescribed by rules of court.
For the purposes of this Act and the uniform rules, carry on proceedings includes defend proceedings.

level.toc-caption: [s 19.5] Rules relating to carrying on proceedings

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 19.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

heading.title: Rules relating to carrying on proceedings

p.text: The provisions of the UCPR directly related to the commencement and defence of proceedings are as follows:

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 20] s 20 Claims for possession of land (cf Act No 52 1970, section 79)

leg:heading.title: Claims for possession of land (cf Act No 52 1970, section 79)

p.text: A claim for judgment for possession of land takes the place of a claim in an action for ejectment that could have been brought under the practice of the Supreme Court as it was immediately before 1 July 1972.
1 July 1972 was the date of commencement of the Supreme Court Act 1970.
Legislation cited in [s 20.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 16.4, UCPR r 39.1(1)(d), UCPR r 39.1(2), 36.8, UCPR r 6.8.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 CPA s 104, CPA s 92.

The procedural requirements that apply to a claim for possession of land are set out in UCPR r 6.8 . A successful claim for possession of land will result in a judgment for possession: CPA s 92 . The judgment is enforceable by a writ for possession: CPA s 104 . A writ for possession may only be issued with leave of the court: UCPR r 39.1(1)(d) . The leave application must comply with UCPR r 39.1(2) . The rules also contain restrictions on a plaintiff’s ability to obtain a judgment for possession of land by default: rr 16.4 , 36.8 . As to the limited ability of a plaintiff to obtain possession by forcible re-entry, see Lobel v McIntosh (NSWSC, Enderby J, 22 June 1992, unreported, BC9201793) and on appeal Lobel v McIntosh (1993) 30 NSWLR 441; BC9303915 .
Legislation cited in [s 20.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Conveyancing Act 1919 s 66G.

At common law the action of trespass was available to those whose actual possession of land was interfered with by an unauthorised entry. Where a person who was not in actual possession of the land, nevertheless had an immediate right to obtain possession their remedy lay in the action of ejectment. Ejectment was originally designed to protect a tenant for a term of years, but it gradually developed into the principal cause of action for recovering possession of land: Holdsworth, A History of English Law, Vol 3, pp 214–17. To succeed in an action of ejectment the plaintiff had to show their right to possession of the land as against the occupier. Actual possession prior to that of the defendant might suffice: Perry v Clissold (1906) 4 CLR 374; [1907] AC 73 ; Allen v Roughley (1955) 94 CLR 98 ; NRMA Insurance Ltd v B & B Shipping and Marine Salvage Co Pty Ltd (1947) 47 SR (NSW) 273; 64 WN (NSW) 58 ; Hawdon v Khan (1920) 20 SR (NSW) 703 ; Oxford Meat Co Pty Ltd v McDonald [1963] NSWR 1244; [1963] SR (NSW) 423 ; Dawson v Pyne (1895) 16 LR (NSW) 116; although it was open to the defendant to show the prior right to possession of a third person; Doe d Carter v Barnard (1849) 13 QB 945; 116 ER 1524 ; Wood v Eisen (1948) 48 SR (NSW) 5 at 13; except where they were a trespasser as against the plaintiff; Davison v Gent (1857) 1 H & N 744; or derive their own claim to possession through the plaintiff: Dalton v Fitzgerald [1897] 2 Ch 86 ; Smith v Smythe (1890) 11 LR (NSW) 295; Dudley v Brown (1888) 14 VLR 655 . A plaintiff who only had an agreement for a lease could not recover in ejectment: JC Williamson Ltd v Durno Ltd (1915) 15 SR (NSW) 442; 32 WN (NSW) 142 . Neither could a shareholder in a home unit company whose articles conferred a right to exclusive possession of part of the company’s land, at least where there has been no grant of a lease nor any actual entry into possession by the shareholder: HH Halls Ltd v Lepouris [1964–5] NSWR 1535; (1964) 65 SR (NSW) 181 . A trustee for sale appointed under s 66G of the Conveyancing Act 1919 could maintain an action in ejectment against a beneficiary who was in occupation of the land: MacDiarmid v MacDiarmid (1956) 74 WN (NSW) 170 .

The claimant’s right to possession may depend on the valid termination of a lease for a term of years. In early times this required physical re-entry. However, because of the fictitious “Doe v Roe” procedure by which a person seeking to defend a right to possession had to admit re-entry, it came to be held that the issue of a writ in ejectment was equivalent to physical re-entry: see McKinnon v Portelli (1959) 60 SR (NSW) 343 for the relevant history. This section continues the effect of service of court proceedings as the equivalent of a re-entry though it is the service of a statement of claim for possession and not the notice to quit which is the equivalent to re-entry: Jewel Food Stores Pty Ltd v Mandalenakis (NSWSC, Ash J, 26 March 1981, unreported); Canas Property Co Ltd v KL Television Services Ltd [1970] 2 QB 433 (service, not the mere issue, of proceedings terminates the lease. Consequently rent is recoverable until the date of service of the writ (not merely to the date of the breach giving rise to the right of re-entry). Thereafter the plaintiff may be entitled to mesne profits: Canas Property , above; Elliot v Boynton [1924] 1 Ch 236 . As to the limited ability of a plaintiff to obtain possession by forcible re-entry, see Lobel v McIntosh (NSWSC, Enderby J, 22 June 1992, unreported, BC9201793).
Legislation cited in [s 20.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 6.18.

In its historical origin a form of action of trespass, a claim for mesne profits is a claim to recover the loss suffered by the wrongful occupation of the defendant. “Mesne profits are the pecuniary benefits deemed to be lost to the person entitled to possession of land, or to rents and profits, by reason of his being wrongfully excluded”: Broadly v Tobiasen [1955] SASR 50 at 52 . The entitlement to mesne profits depends upon the plaintiff's possession of the land, or their right to obtain immediate possession. Thus, the claim cannot be made by a plaintiff not in possession if it is asserted independently of proceedings claiming an order for possession: Minister for the Interior v RT Co Pty Ltd (1963) 107 CLR 1; [1963] ALR 57 ; McVicar v Jackson (1957) 75 WN (NSW) 46 ; Brennan v Thomas [1953] VLR 111 ; and historically the claim was made in separate proceedings commenced after judgment for possession had been obtained: see now r 6.18 (which permits joinder of causes of action). The normal measure is the market rental value of the property and any consequential diminution in its value as a result of direct damage. It is immaterial that the plaintiff cannot show either that they could or would have re-let the property and the actual use to which the defendant put the land is to be considered if it has increased the rental value of the property, and this is so irrespective whether or not the plaintiff would have used the land in the same way: Jegon v Vivian (1871) LR 6 Ch App 742; Whitwham v Westminster Brymbo Coal Co [1896] 2 Ch 538 ; Penarth Dock Engineering Co v Pounds [1963] 1 Lloyd’s Rep 359; Swardheath Properties v Tabet [1979] 1 WLR 285 .

level.toc-caption: [s 20.25] Defences to a claim for possession of land

heading.title: Defences to a claim for possession of land

p.text: Where the defendant obtained possession under a lease the tenancy must be validly determined either by re-entry, notice to quit or, in the case of a tenancy at will, by demand: Roth v Roth [1960] NSWR 548; (1960) 78 WN (NSW) 510 ; Stewart v Bolton (1882) 8 VLR (L) 305; Sandhurst Mutual Permanent Investment Building Society v Gissing (1889) 15 VLR 329 . Where the defendant is a licensee, the licence is no defence to an action for ejectment: Lanhams Properties Pty Ltd v Sayers [1961] NSWR 947; (1961) 79 WN (NSW) 265 ; Leese v Davis (1951) 71 WN (NSW) 39 ; Narooma Motels Pty Ltd v Champion [1961] SR (NSW) 473 ; unless the “licence” is a statutory right: Abigail Pty Ltd v Rudder [1967] 1 NSWR 671; (1967) 86 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 76 . A person who has a right of entry under a sharefarming agreement is a licensee and has no right of exclusive possession so as to afford a defence to a claim for possession of the land: Hindmarsh v Quinn (1914) 17 CLR 622; 20 ALR 339 ; Killiby v Farthing (1954) 55 SR (NSW) 85; 72 WN (NSW) 44 ; Dudgeon v Chie (1955) 92 CLR 342; 29 ALJR 415 ; Moxey v Lawrence (1952) 69 WN (NSW) 378 .

If there are mutual debts between a plaintiff and a defendant in any proceedings, the defendant may, by way of defence, set off against the plaintiff’s claim any debt that is owed by the plaintiff to the defendant and that was due and payable at the time the defence of set-off was filed, whether or not the mutual debts are different in nature.
This section extends to civil proceedings in which one or more of the mutual debts is owed by or to a deceased person who is represented by a legal personal representative.
This section does not apply to the extent to which the plaintiff and defendant have agreed that debts (whether generally or as to specific debts) may not be set off against each other.
This section does not affect any other rights or obligations of a debtor or creditor in respect of mutual debts, whether arising in equity or otherwise.
This section is subject to section 120 of the Industrial Relations Act 1996.
In this section, debt means any liquidated claim.
The application of this provision to existing debts is dealt with in clause 6 of Schedule 6 (Savings, transitional and other provisions).
Legislation cited in [s 21.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Imperial Acts Application Act 1969.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 78.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 Pt 15 r 25.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 21(4).

The section re-introduces a statutory right of set-off in New South Wales. It completes a procedural history that had its starting point in Stehar Knitting Mills Pty Ltd v Southern Textile Convertors Pty Ltd [1980] 2 NSWLR 514 . In that case the NSW Court of Appeal held that the imperial statutes of set-off had been repealed in their application to NSW by the Imperial Acts Application Act 1969 . But, distinguishing Hanak v Green [1958] 2 QB 9 , the court held that a separate right of set-off existed as a result of the combined effect of s 78 of the Supreme Court Act and Pt 15 r 25 of the Supreme Court Rules. That right was more extensive than both the previous statutory right and the equitable right, because it extended to any “contrary” money liabilities, including those in unascertained amounts and irrespective of any absence of connection between the circumstances that gave rise to the liabilities. However this liberalisation of the law of set-off was short-lived. Part 15 r 25 was repealed in 1983–84 as a result of preference for the view that only the equitable right of set-off should be recognised: Sydmar Pty Ltd v Statewise Developments Pty Ltd (1987) 73 ALR 289 at 292; 11 ACLR 616 . The consequence of the repeal was that mutual debts could no longer be pleaded as a defence — unless the debt also gave rise a right of equitable set-off or was available under insolvency legislation: AWA Ltd v Exicom Australia Pty Ltd (1990) 19 NSWLR 705 . This was the position that prevailed at the time of the reference to the Law Reform Commission in 1997. The commission’s February 2000 Report 94, Set-off, recommended the reinroduction of a statutory right of set-off, but one restricted to “mutual” debts involving liquidated claims that are due and payable when the defence is filed. The present section gives effect to the commission’s recommendations and the statutory right of set-off does not extend to unliquidated claims. It is also restricted to “mutual” debts. Because of these restrictions s 21(4) is expressed not to affect any other rights of set-off and does not, therefore, affect any equitable rights of set-off.
Legislation cited in [s 21.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 21.

A defendant may rely on a defence of equitable set-off, whether or not the contrary claims are “mutual” in the sense required by the statutory right in s 21 , and irrespective of whether or not both claims involve liquidated demands. The right of set off in equity depends on the more general proposition that the contrary liabilities are sufficiently closely connected that it would be inequitable for the plaintiff to be permitted to proceed with its claim without making allowance for the defendant’s claim against it: Roadshaw Entertainment Pty Ltd v ACN 053 006 269 Pty Ltd (1997) 42 NSWLR 462 ; Murphy v Zamonex Pty Ltd (1993) 31 NSWLR 439 at 463–8 (followed in Doherty v Murphy [1996] 2 VR 553 ); J & S Holdings Pty Ltd v NRMA Insurance Ltd (1982) 41 ALR 539; 61 FLR 108 ; Lord v Direct Acceptance Corp (in liq) (1993) 32 NSWLR 362 ; Indrisie v General Credits Ltd [1985] VR 251 ; Gibb Australia Pty Ltd v Cremor Pty Ltd (1992) 108 FLR 129 ; AWA Ltd v Exicom Australia Pty Ltd (1990) 19 NSWLR 705 at 712 , 714 ; Australian Mutual Provident Society v Specialist Funding Consultants Pty Ltd (1991) 24 NSWLR 326 at 328–9 (some claims for damages for breach of contract may be set off against a claim for an amount due under the contract); Westmex Operations Pty Ltd (in liq) v Westmex Ltd (in liq) (1992) 8 ACSR 146 at 153 . It is accepted that the defence will be available where the defendants claim “impeaches” the plaintiff's title: Rawson v Samuel (1841) Cr & Ph 154; 41 ER 451; McDonnell & East Ltd v McGregor (1936) 56 CLR 50 at 60; [1936] ALR 324 ; Re Just Juice Corp Pty Ltd (1992) 8 ACSR 444 at 460–2 ; James v Commonwealth Bank of Australia (1992) 37 FCR 445 . This will be the case where the two claims are interdependent, for example, where the plaintiff's default contributed to the defendant's liability: Grant v NZMC Ltd [1989] 1 NZLR 8 at 13 ; Re Just Juice , above. There is some controversy as to whether the defence will also lie where the defendant's claim does not “impeach” the plaintiff's title directly — even though both arise out of the same transaction: see Derham, “Recent issues in relation to set-off” (1994) 68 ALJ 331; Walker v Secretary, Dept of Social Security (1995) 56 FCR 354; 129 ALR 198 at 206–10 . Many authorities take the view that it is insufficient to show merely that the claims arise out of the same transaction: Re KL Tractors Ltd [1954] VLR 505 ; The Leon [1985] 2 Lloyd’s Rep 470; Spry, “Equitable set-offs” (1969) 43 ALJ 265 at 268; The Aditya Vaibhav [1991] 1 Lloyd’s Rep 573. But there are other authorities that favour a wider basis for the defence and would regard it as available whenever the two claims arise out of the same transaction and are “inseparably” connected: Bank of Boston Connecticut v European Grain & Shipping Ltd [1989] 1 AC 1056; Henriksens Rederi A/S v THZ Rolimpex (The Brede) [1974] QB 233 ; Government of Newfoundland v Newfoundland Railway Co (1888) 13 App Cas 199; [1886–90] All ER Rep Ext 1590 . It has even been said that the case law has not produced a test by which the relevant principle can be readily stated: Signature Resorts Pty Ltd v DHD Constructions Pty Ltd (1995) 18 ACSR 627 at 634 . Whatever the precise formulation of the actual test, relevant circumstances to have regard to are the nature of the claims, the nature of the connection between them and the conduct of the parties: D Galambos & Son Pty Ltd v McIntyre (1974) 5 ACTR 10 at 26 ; Sydmar Pty Ltd v Statewise Developments Pty Ltd (1987) 73 ALR 289 at 296; 11 ACLR 616 ; CSR Investments Pty Ltd v Alcan Northern Territory Alumina Pty Ltd [2003] NSWSC 1137; BC200307495 at [41] . This includes, for example, any delay by the defendant in pursuing the cross-demand: Bank of New Zealand v Harry M Miller & Co Ltd (1992) 26 NSWLR 48 (surety entitled to set off the amount deposited with a creditor against a demand made by the creditors assignee).

The requirement for mutuality under the Statutes of Set-off was interpreted as requiring both identity of parties involved in both liquidated claims and also identity of the capacities in which the liability arose: S R Derham, Set-off, 2nd ed, 1996, Clarendon Press, Oxford at 319. The Law Reform Commission’s Report 94 considered that this approach would continue to apply to the statutory right of set-off under the present section.
Where an employee sues to recover remuneration, s 120(1) of the Industrial Relations Act 1996 precludes an employer from pleading any set off for goods or services it has supplied to the employee.

level.toc-caption: [s 21.25] Judgments and orders for costs — set-off

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 21.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 90(2).

heading.title: Judgments and orders for costs — set-off

p.text: CPA s 90(2) permits a court to give judgment for the balance of the claims and cross-claims between the parties to the proceedings. The provision in CPA s 90(2) is similar to rules in many jurisdictions which specifically permit the court to set off judgments and to give a single judgment for the balance in favour of the successful party. There is authority for the view that, even in the absence of such a provision, the court has power to order that one judgment be set off against another: Ryan v South Sydney Junior Rugby League Club Ltd [1975] 2 NSWLR 660 ; Bank of New South Wales v Preston (1894) 20 VLR 1 ; Wentworth v Wentworth (NSWCA, Priestley and Clarke JJA & Grove AJA, 21 February 1996, unreported, BC9600213), approving Wentworth v Wentworth (NSWSC, Young J, 3748/89, 12 December 1994, unreported, BC9403409) (set-off of costs orders).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 22] s 22 Defendant’s right to cross-claim (cf Act No 52 1970, section 78; Act No 11 1970, section 15; DCR Part 20, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: Defendant’s right to cross-claim (cf Act No 52 1970, section 78; Act No 11 1970, section 15; DCR Part 20, rule 1)

p.text: Subject to subsection (2), the court may grant to the defendant in any proceedings (the first proceedings) such relief against any person (whether or not a plaintiff in the proceedings) as the court might grant against that person in separate proceedings commenced by the defendant for that purpose.
Relief may not be granted under this section against a person who is not a plaintiff in the first proceedings unless the relief relates to, or is connected with, the subject of the first proceedings.
A person against whom a defendant makes a claim for relief under this section:
has the same rights in respect of his or her defence against the claim as he or she would have in separate proceedings commenced against the person by the defendant, and
if not already a party to the first proceedings:
becomes a party to the first proceedings, and

unless the court otherwise orders, is bound by any judgment (including a judgment by consent or by default) or decision (including a decision by consent) on any claim for relief in the proceedings (including a claim for relief in any cross-claim in the proceedings).

level.toc-caption: [s 22.5] Cross-claims by a defendant — procedural finality

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 22.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Copyright Act 1968 s 22.

heading.title: Cross-claims by a defendant — procedural finality

p.text: The section complements other provisions of the CPA and the UCPR intended to promote the final resolution of litigious controversy between the parties involved. Under its provisions, a defendant may cross-claim against individual plaintiffs: Manchester Sheffield & Lincolnshire Railway Co v Brooks (1877) 2 Ex D 243 : or against co-defendants or third parties (subject to the requirement of a sufficient connection with the subject matter of the plaintiff’s proceedings: Burnside v Harrison Marks Productions Ltd [1968] 2 All ER 286; [1968] 1 WLR 782 ). The section is procedural only and the substantive right to claim contribution must exist independently: Dillingham Constructions Pty Ltd v Steel Mains Pty Ltd (1975) 132 CLR 323; 6 ALR 171; 49 ALJR 233; BC7500032 (no entitlement to claim contribution under s 5 of the Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1946 where the causes of action substantially arose from merely successive injuries, even though the later injuries exacerbated the consequences of the previous injury). However, if there is a substantive right the court may make orders against one defendant and in favour of another, even in the absence of a formal claim, either because it is a necessary incident of the relief sought by the plaintiff or pursuant to s 22 : Adamopoulos v Olympic Airways SA (1991) 25 NSWLR 75 .
Legislation cited in [s 22.7] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Copyright Act 1968 s 3.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 19.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 588FGA(4).

CPA s 3 defines a “defendant” as a person against whom proceedings are commenced including proceedings by way of cross-claim. However SCA s 19 defines a defendant as including any person who is entitled to attend any proceedings. It follows that, at least in proceedings in the Supreme Court, entities that have a statutory right to intervene in proceedings may cross-claim under the present section: Permanent Trustee Australia Ltd v Dowd (1993) 11 ACSR 68; 11 ACLC 792; BC9301821 ; State Bank of New South Wales Ltd v White [1999] NSWSC 887; BC9905490 — subject to contrary limitations in the relevant statutory provision: Condon v Cmr of Taxation (2004) 207 ALR 676; 49 ACSR 681; [2004] NSWSC 481; BC200403299 (procedural restriction governing claims under s 588FGA(4) of the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth)). Other statutory provisions may also permit a defendant to claim against third parties in relation to the subject matter of the proceedings: Condon v Cmr of Taxation, above (defendant in preference proceedings entitled to claim indemnity from directors pursuant to s 588FGA(4) of the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth)).

level.toc-caption: [s 22.10] Cross claims — degree of connection required

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 22.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Copyright Act 1968 s 22(2).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 9.1, r 9.8.

heading.title: Cross claims — degree of connection required

p.text: The section permits a defendant to bring any cross-claim against a plaintiff. It also permits cross-claims against third parties where the cross-claim is connected with the subject matter of the plaintiff’s claim: DG Madin Ltd v Gordon [1964] SASR 64 at 66 . The degree of connection sufficient to justify a cross claim against a third party is prescribed in CPA s 22(2) in generous terms that do not expressly require a substantial degree of similarity, but its presence or absence is likely to influence the exercise of any procedural discretion in relation to the conduct of any proceedings on the cross claim: see Chatsworth Investments Ltd v Amoco (UK) Ltd [1968] 1 Ch 665 at 674 and see generally s 65.40 for a relevant analogy). The right to cross-claim conferred by UCPR r 9.1 is subject to the present section, and leaves the court with a discretion to refuse to allow a cross-claim in the proceedings: Schneider v Batt & Co (1882) 8 QBD 701 at 705 ; Wood v Cross Television Centre Pty Ltd [1962] NSWR 528; (1961) 79 WN (NSW) 596 . However, if the proposed cross-claim has a relevant connection with the subject matter of the proceedings, and is brought in a timely fashion, it will usually be appropriate to make facilitating directions under r 9.8 of the UCPR rather than to disallow the cross-claim in the proceedings: see [9.8.5] and [9.10.5] .

level.toc-caption: [s 22.12] Claims and Cross claims — effect of determination on parties

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 22.12] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Copyright Act 1968 s 22(3).
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 78(4).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 9.8.

heading.title: Claims and Cross claims — effect of determination on parties

p.text: As a consequence of CPA s 22(3) , cross-defendants are parties to the proceedings and will be bound by the determination of issues between the plaintiff and defendant — subject to any contrary order: Sandtara Pty Ltd v Abigroup Ltd (1997) 42 NSWLR 5; [1998] ANZ ConvR 104; BC9703416 ; Insurance Exchange of Australasia Group v Dooley (2000) 50 NSWLR 222 at 226; [2000] NSWCA 159; BC200004689 (a decision under s 78(4) of the SCA) — disapproving Berkeley Challenge Pty Ltd v Potbury (NSWCA, Meagher, Sheller and Powell JJA, No 40472/95, 18 December 1997, unreported, BC9707075): see also [9.10.5] . Under UCPR r 9.8 the court can make specific directions determining the extent to which the cross-claim should be separately tried and modifying trial procedures as a consequence of the cross-claim. Subject to any such directions, cross-defendants bound by the determination of issues in the proceedings are generally entitled to participate in the hearing of the proceedings between the plaintiff and the defendant. As a general principle, cross-defendants ought be permitted to rely on any matter that operates as a defence to the plaintiff's claim against the principal defendant: Barclays Bank v Tom [1923] 1 KB 221 at 224; [1922] All ER Rep 279 ; Eden v Weardale Iron & Coal Co (1887) 35 Ch D 287 .

level.toc-caption: [s 22.15] Cross-claim before determination of plaintiff's claim

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 22.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 9.11(1).

heading.title: Cross-claim before determination of plaintiff's claim

p.text: The section permits a defendant to cross-claim to recover a contractual indemnity: Port of Melbourne Authority v Anshun Pty Ltd (1981) 147 CLR 589 at 595; 36 ALR 3; 55 ALJR 621; BC8100097 ; or for contribution under the Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1946 : Andrews v Nominal Defendant [1963] NSWR 359; [1963] SR (NSW) 110 at 117; (1962) 80 WN (NSW) 82 ; before the actual determination of the defendant's own liability to the plaintiff. This permission applies notwithstanding that a defendant could not otherwise maintain separate proceedings for contribution until its own liability to the “victim” had been determined, either by judgment or settlement: Baldry v Jackson [1976]1 NSWLR 19; Bitumen and Oil Refineries (Aust) Ltd v Cmr for Government Transport (1955) 92 CLR 200 at 212; [1955] ALR 325; 55 SR (NSW) 108; BC5500620 ; Nickels v Parks (1948) 49 SR (NSW) 124; 65 WN (NSW) 273 . However a defendant cannot enter judgment on the cross-claim without leave, and cannot enforce the indemnity or contribution judgment, until their own liability has been satisfied: see UCPR r 9.11(1) .

level.toc-caption: [s 22.20] Set-off of claims where there is a cross-claim

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 22.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 90(2).

heading.title: Set-off of claims where there is a cross-claim

p.text: Under CPA s 90(2) , the court has a discretion to enter judgment for the balance only of the sums of money awarded on the respective claims, or may give judgment in respect of each claim: see further [s 21.25] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 23] s 23 Effect of abandoning excess claim (cf Act No 9 1973, section 50; Act No 11 1970, section 14)

leg:heading.title: Effect of abandoning excess claim (cf Act No 9 1973, section 50; Act No 11 1970, section 14)

p.text: If, in any proceedings on a claim, the cause of action giving rise to the claim is for more than the court’s jurisdictional limit:
the person may abandon the excess by a statement to that effect in the originating process, and
in that event, the person’s claim is taken to be reduced by the amount of the excess.
If a person’s claim is successful in respect of a cause of action:
the amount recoverable by the person (exclusive of costs and interest) is not to exceed the court’s jurisdictional limit, and
the judgment in the proceedings is in full discharge of all of the person’s demands in respect of that cause of action, and
entry of the judgment in the records of the court is to be made accordingly.
This section is subject to section 51 of the District Court Act 1973 and section 31 of the Local Court Act 2007.
Under those sections, claims in the District Court or the Local Court for amounts in excess of the court’s jurisdictional limit can, in some cases, be dealt with by consent of parties.
[subs (3) am Act 94 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1.12[1], s 4 and Sch 2, effective 6 July 2009]

level.toc-caption: [s 23.5] Entitlement to abandon part of claim

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 23.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Local Courts (Civil Claims) Act 1970 s 14.

heading.title: Entitlement to abandon part of claim

p.text: This section re-enacts provisions previously found in Local Courts (Civil Claims) Act 1970 s 14 and the Small Debts Recovery Act 1912 s 14 . It is directed at reversing the effect of decisions which had held that parties could not overcome the jurisdictional limits of statutory courts by attempts to set-off or abandon parts of their claims: Ex parte Brough (1874) 12 SCR (NSW) 368 and Ex parte Noel (1905) 5 SR (NSW) 445; 22 WN (NSW) 131 (setting off a sum of money in the one case and executing a deed of release abandoning the excess without the defendant's knowledge or consent in the other). The section is obviously not concerned with the Supreme Court whose jurisdiction is unlimited.

level.toc-caption: [s 23.10] Effect of abandonment where jurisdiction altered

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 23.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Local Court Act 2007 s 30(5).
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 143(2)(a).

heading.title: Effect of abandonment where jurisdiction altered

p.text: If the jurisdictional limit of the court is increased while the proceedings are still pending the court may make an order altering the amount specified in the claim to an amount not exceeding the new jurisdictional limit: Local Court Act 2007 s 30(5) — apparently notwithstanding any prior abandonment. Where proceedings are transferred to a higher court, any abandonment under CPA s 23 ceases to have effect except in relation to any jurisdictional limits of the higher court: CPA s 143(2)(a) .
Legislation cited in [s 23.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 23(1)(a).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 6.12(6).

The abandonment must be stated “by a statement to that effect in the originating process”: CPA s 23(1)(a) . Merely filing a statement of claim for part of the claim does not constitute an abandonment of the excess: Vines v Arnold (1849) 8 CB 632; 137 ER 655. Neither can the court amend a claim without a party’s consent in order to bring it within the court’s jurisdiction: Re Hill (1855) 10 Exch 726; 156 ER 632. However, no particular formality is required: Waxman v M'Auliffe (1879) 5 VLR (L) 48 (sufficient to include a general statement of abandonment “of all excess of any claims over and above the sum of ($x)”). And it would seem that any failure to comply with formalities of the section is still capable of being cured by amendment, in the same way as a failure to claim pre-judgment interest in the originating process as required by UCPR r 6.12(6) is also capable of being cured by amendment: see Heath v Goodwin (1986) 8 NSWLR 478 . Thus, in Segur v Franklin (1934) 34 SR (NSW) 67; 51 WN (NSW) 31 , the trial judge was held to be wrong to refuse a request made at the trial for leave to amend the claim by abandoning the excess.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 24] s 24 Effect of splitting cause of action (cf Act No 9 1973, section 49; Act No 11 1970, section 13)

leg:heading.title: Effect of splitting cause of action (cf Act No 9 1973, section 49; Act No 11 1970, section 13)

p.text: If:

a person (the first person) splits any cause of action against another person (the other person) so as to commence proceedings, or make a cross-claim, for part only of the amount for which proceedings may be commenced on that cause, and
judgment is given or entered, or a final order is made, on the proceedings or cross-claim,
the other person is entitled to judgment in any other proceedings, whether in that or any other court, with respect to the same cause of action.
Despite subsection (1), if the other person has given a number of securities in respect of a claim made by the first person, the first person:
may commence proceedings in any court in respect of each of those securities, or
may make a cross-claim in proceedings in any court in respect of each of those securities,

as if each of those securities gave rise to a distinct cause of action, and may do so whether or not the claim made by the first person is for an amount that is more than the court’s jurisdictional limit.
Legislation cited in [s 24.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 24(1).

The prohibition on splitting or dividing causes of action is a feature of legislation governing courts whose jurisdiction is subject to monetary limits and operates to prevent related claims being divided into multiple proceedings purely for the purpose of bringing each within the limits of the court's jurisdiction. Under s 24(1) , a judgment operates as a defence to any claim on a “split” component of the same cause of action: see generally Sollimano v Nolan [1921] VLR 389 and Adkin v Friend (1878) 38 LT 393 .
The following claims have been held to constitute “split” causes of action:
claims based on different items on a running account between the parties: Re Aykroyd; Grimbly v Aykroyd (1848) 1 Exch 479; 154 ER 204: Bonsey v Wordsworth (1856) 18 CB 328; 139 ER 1395;
claims for trespass to land and trespass to goods arising out of the same events: Ex parte Madden (1876) 14 SCR (NSW) 437.
The following have been held not to involve “split” causes of action:
claims based on a running account for goods sold and a claim for repayment of a loan: Brunskill v Powell (1850) 19 LJ Ex 3262;
a claim to recover commission and a claim for indemnity for goods purchased as agent: Ex parte Delaforce (1888) 4 WN (NSW) 165;
claims for moneys due under, and claims for damages for breach of, a contract: Ex parte Watkins (1902) 19 WN (NSW) 265 ; Overstone Ltd v Shipway [1962] 1 All ER 52 (instalment contract);
claims for trespass to goods, and trespass to person, arising out of the same events: Brunsden v Humphrey (1884) 14 QBD 141 ;
claims for rent and claims for holding over after expiry of the tenancy: Wickham v Lee (1848) 12 QB 521; 116 ER 963 ; and

plaintiff held entitled to sue for damages for trespass to lands in one action and for damage to his ewes in another action, both causes of action being founded upon the trespass of the defendant's rams on the plaintiff's property. However, the plaintiff was precluded from succeeding in the second action by a plea of judgment recovered.
